Email: bcschipper@ucdavis.edu1 Introduction Decisions in the face of risk and uncertainty have been at least as pervasive in the past of human mankind as they are in present. While today a decision maker's economic success or overall success in life is a ected by her risk preferences, it is conceivable that in the past also reproductive success was in uenced by risk preferences. Thus, evolutionary selection has probably acted on traits that a ect how a decision maker takes decisions under risk and uncertainty (see Robson 1996, Dekel and Scotchmer 1999, and Hamo and Heifetz, 2002, for theoretical models). These traits should have biological markers. In this paper we study rather comprehensively to what extent some biological factors like hormones are associated with risk preferences. Hormones are chemical messengers that transport signals from one cell to another. Finding hormones that are associated with risk preferences allows us to learn about the biological mechanisms involved in decision making under risk. The empirical literature on risk preferences studied the association with gender, one biological factor relevant to hormones. In summarizing the sizeable literature, Croson and Gneezy (2009, p. 2) write that \(t)he robust nding is that men are more risk-prone than are women." Similarly, Eckel and Grossman (2008) state that \in most studies, women are found to be more averse to risk than men. Studies with contextual frames show less consistent results".1A more recent review by Filippin and Crosetto (2014) strikes a more cautionary note in concluding that \gender di erences are less ubiquitous than usually depicted." From an evolutionary point of view, gender di erences in risk preferences would not be too surprising because males and females play di erent roles in human reproduction. Males and females di er also in circulating levels of various sex hormones like testosterone, estradiol, and progesterone. Thus, gender di erences in risk preferences suggest that risk preferences may also vary by sex hormones. In this paper, we study the association of risk preferences for both gains and losses with salivary testosterone, estradiol, progesterone, and cortisol. Testosterone is a steroid hormone that has anabolic e ects such as stimulating the bone density and muscle mass as well as androgenic e ects such as the maturation of sex organs and secondary sex characteristics especially in males. Since it is observed in most vertebrates, it must have had a long evolutionary history (Mechoulam et al., 1984). In humans, testosterone is associated with aggression (e.g. Archer, 1991, Dabbs and Hargrove, 1997) and dominance (e.g. Mazur and Booth, 1998, Mehta and Josephs, 2006) especially in males. More importantly for our study, testosterone has been previously associated with risk preferences. Apicella et al. (2008) nd a signi cant negative correlation between basal salivary testosterone and risk aversion in choice under risk for males. Sapienza et al. (2009) nd an insigni cant weak negative association between salivary testosterone and risk aversion in males but a signi cant negative relationship in females. Stanton et al. (2011a) nd a negative 1See also Byrnes, Miller, and Schafer (1999) for any earlier review of the literature. 2association for both genders in a gambling task that had not been incentivized. Stanton et al. (2011b) report a u-shaped relationship between risk attitudes and salivary testosterone in both genders, where individuals with high or low testosterone are approximately risk neutral and individuals with intermediate levels of testosterone are risk averse. Using a placebo-controlled experiment and a sample of 200 postmenopausal women, Zethraeus et al. (2009) did not nd a signi cant association between randomly administered testosterone or estrogen and risk-taking. In our current study, we replicate the nding by Apicella et al. (2008) with a di erent lottery experiment. That is, we show that in males testosterone is signi cantly positively associated with risk taking in males in Holt-Laury lottery tasks in the gain domain. We show a null result for the loss domain, which is new. Moreover, we observe null results for females both in the gain and loss domains. We measure risk preferences using a lottery task due to Holt and Laury (2002), which consists of presenting each subject of our experiment with a list of pairs of lotteries. The subject has to make choices between the lotteries for each pair of lotteries in the list (see Section 2.1). The probability of outcomes varies systematically across the list of lottery pairs. While this design has been originally applied to lotteries involving monetary gains only, Laury and Holt (2008) extend it also to lotteries involving monetary losses. This allows for studying postulates of prospect theory (see Kahneman and Tversky, 1979, and Tversky and Kahneman, 1992) such as the re ection e ect, i.e., risk aversion for gains and risk seeking for losses.2 While salivary testosterone has been previously studied, we also include salivary estradiol, progesterone, and cortisol in our study. We are not aware of any other study that analyzes the association of risk preferences with these hormones. Estradiol is also a steroid hormone that has anabolic e ects on the bone structure and androgenic e ects on the maturation of female sex organs and secondary sex characteristics. Progesterone is a steroid hormone as well. It is secreted in the ovaries, especially the corpus luteum, the adrenal glands, and during pregnancy in the placenta. There is evidence that increases in progesterone are positively associated with women's avoidance of \social risks" such as infections as re ected in behavior in public bathrooms (Fleischman and Fessler, 2011), increased attention to social stimuli (Maner and Miller, 2014) as well as non-conscious needs to have close, friendly relationships with others (Schultheiss, Wirth, and Stanton, 2004, Wirth and Schultheiss, 2006, Brown et al., 2009). In a companion study, Schipper (2014) nds that progesterone is signi cantly positively associated with bidding of females in rst-price auctions, which in theory is consistent with a positive association of progesterone with risk aversion. Finally, we include the steroid hormone cortisol. Cortisol is correlated with stress (Dickerson and Kemeny, Wuest, and Kudielka, 2009) and thus we nd it intuitive that it may be correlated with risk preferences as well. Besides the testosterone result for males discussed above, we observe null results for all hormones by gender 2See Harrison and Ruthstr om (2008) for a survey on experiments on risk preferences. 3except for cortisol. Cortisol is signi cantly positively associated with risk aversion for gains in females only. Some sex hormones like progesterone and estradiol vary over the menstrual cycle. Estradiol peaks during the midcycle and again in the second half of the cycle. Progesterone rises after ovulation. There is some mixed evidence of the association of bidding behavior in rst-price auctions with menstrual cycle phases. Recall that in the theory of rst-price auctions, bids are positively associated with risk aversion. Pearson and Schipper (2013) show that in rst-price auctions women bid similarly to men during ovulation but signi cantly higher in other phases of their menstrual cycle. Chen, Katu s c ak, and Ozdenoren (2013) report that women bid higher than men in all phases of their menstrual cycle in a symmetric independent private value rst-price auction but not in a second-price auction. In our study, we also elicited menstrual cycle information from female subjects and observe no association of risk preferences for gains and losses with menstrual cycle phases. This is consistent with a very recent unpublished study by Drichoutis and Nayga (2013) who also do not nd an association of risk preferences with menstrual cycle phases. Some females in our sample use hormonal contraceptives. All hormonal contraceptives contain a progestin, a synthetic version of progesterone. We are not aware of studies on how hormonal contraceptives could a ect behavior except Pearson and Schipper (2013) and Schipper (2014) who show that the use of hormonal contraceptives is positively associated with bidding in rst-price auctions. This could be due to the hormonal contraceptives or to a selection e ect. In our study we report that females who use hormonal contraceptives do not have risk preferences di erent from naturally cycling females. Yet, risk preferences of females on hormonal contraceptives appear to be more \consistent" than risk preferences of naturally cycling females. Behavior may not just be a ected by circulating hormones levels but also by prenatal exposure to certain hormones. We are interested in what sense risk preferences may be in uenced by biological events before birth. We use as a putative biological marker the ratio between the length of the 2nd (index) nger and the 4th (ring) nger of the subjects' right hand (so called \digit ratio" or 2D:4D). (See Manning, 2002, for an introduction.) The digit ratio is thought to be positively correlated with prenatal exposure to estrogen and negatively correlated to prenatal exposure to testosterone (Manning et al., 1998, Lutchmaya et al., 2004, H onekopp et al., 2007). On average, men have lower 2D:4D than women. 2D:4D is to a large extent genetically determined (Paul et al., 2006), but it may also be a ected by the environment in utero . In any case, 2D:4D is determined before birth and thus before common economic, social, and cultural factors could shape risk preferences of the individual directly. Dreber and Ho man (2007) and Garbarino et al. (2011) show that risk-taking in investment tasks are signi cantly negatively correlated with 2D:4D in white subjects but Apicella et al. (2008) show that this is not the case in a racially more mixed male sample. Sapienza et al. (2009) do not nd a signi cant correlation 4between risk aversion and 2D:4D in a lottery task except for a marginal signi cant positive correlation for females in a sample of 550 MBA students. In a recent study, Drichoutis and Nayga (2013) observe no signi cant correlation between 2D:4D and lottery choices in a sample of 138 subjects. Using a questionnaire on various domains of risk, Stenstrom et al. (2011) nd a marginally signi cant negative correlation between nancial risk-taking and digit ratio in males but only null results for recreational, social, ethical, or health risks or females. Bra~ nas Garza and Rustichini (2011) study the correlation between 2D:4D, risk aversion, and abstract reasoning ability. They employ two measures of risk aversion in a sample of 188 Caucasian subjects. One of measures is derived from choices in a Holt-Laury lottery task. For this measure they report a signi cant but negative correlation between the digit ratio and risk aversion for females (for the other measure it is insigni cant). For males they report a nonsigni cant positive correlation between risk aversion and the digit ratio (for the other measure it is signi cant). Roney and van Hippel (2010) report that males with lower 2D:4D show greater risk-taking when primed with low power motivation and lower risk-taking when primed with high power motivation. Ho man, Jordan, and Yoeli (2013) present a meta study of the literature (that includes the present study). Overall they report a signi cant negative correlation between risk-taking and 2D:4D. With respect to this literature on the digit ratio and risk aversion, we essentially replicate the null results by Apicella et al. (2008) with a di erent task for choice under risk. But we also show that the null result extends to females and to choice under risk in the loss domain. Finally, we also study plain gender e ects on risk preferences in gains and losses. Surprisingly, there is no gender e ect on risk preferences for gains in our sample. Yet, in the loss domain females are signi cantly more risk averse than males. Moreover, females appear to have less \consistent" risk preferences than males. The paper is organized as follows: The next section introduces the experimental design and hypotheses. The results are presented in Section 3. Section 4 concludes with a discussion. In both, the gain and loss domains, risk neutrality implies choosing option A ve times, sucient risk aversion implies choosing option A more than ve times, while sucient risk seeking implies choosing option A less than ve times. Thus as a matter of terminology, we say that an individual is risk averse if she chooses option A more than ve time, risk neutral if she chooses option A exactly ve times, and risk seeking if she chooses option A less than ve times. We say that a group X of subjects is more risk averse (resp. more risk seeking) than a group Y if on average it chooses option A more often (resp. less often) than group Y. It is possible to t for each domain the corresponding interval of risk parameters for popular utility functions such as constant relative risk aversion (see Holt and Laury, 2002, Laury and Holt, 2008, Harrison and Ruthstr om, 2008). But we believe that for this correlation study it would add nothing beyond our behavioral de nitions of risk aversion and risk seeking behavior above. Kahneman and Tversky (1979) and Tversky and Kahneman (1992) claim that frequently individuals are risk averse in the gain domain while risk seeking in the loss domain. This is called the re ection e ect. In our experiment, we can study the re ection e ect because conduct lottery tasks both in the gain and loss domains. In our setting, a subject is said to display the re ection e ect if she chooses option A more than ve times in gain domain and less than ve times in the loss domain. Not all subjects may display a unique cut-o for switching between the options but may switch several times between options A and B. Moreover, a subject may not respect dominance and thus may not choose option A and B in Decision No. 1 in the gain and loss domain, respectively. If we observe a subject switching several times, we should not dismiss the preferences too quickly 7as being \inconsistent". We simply don't know why it switches several times. It could be that the subject is just indi erent and that's why when forced to make a choice may switch between options several times. It could also be that the subject is not indi erent but simply makes a mistake in writing down the wrong choice. Finally, it could be that the subject \happily violates" the assumptions underlying the maximization of expected monetary payo s. In any case, the information obtained from subjects who switch several times or choose the dominated option is limited. That's why we call a subject's preference accessible if the subject has an unique cut-o for switching between options and respects dominance. Otherwise, we call the subject's preferences inaccessible . Since our experiment also included auction games, it was advertised as a \market game" mostly via announcements in big classes, in advertisements on Facebook, and through the distribution of lea ets. All sessions were run between February 8 and March 16, 2010, at 16:00. Upon arrival at the lab, subjects were seated randomly at one of nine desks with computer terminals separated by dividers. Each subject faced the wall of the room. Subjects were given a consent form to read and sign. At every session, the same male native-English speaking experimenter was present to explain the instructions and supervise the experiment. Subjects also received one piece of chewing gum - Tridentc Original Flavor - to stimulate saliva (see Dabbs, 1991) as well as a sterilized plastic straw through which to drool about 2.5 ml saliva into the vial. After depositing the saliva, each subject closed the vial by screwing the top and placed it back into the cup. The cups with the vials were collected by the experimenter and immediately frozen. Moreover, as discussed in the introduction, the received view in the prior literature is that females are more risk averse than males. Thus, we hypothesize that females are more risk averse than males in both the gain and loss domains. Hormonal Contraceptives All hormonal contraceptives contain a progestine, a synthetic version of the sex hormone proges- terone. Some contain also a version of estradiol, another sex hormone. Progesterone may have a sedating e ect (see Pluchino et al., 2006, van Broeckhoven et al., 2006).7Throughout the human brain, there are neurons secreting the neurotransmitter GABA. When GABA interacts with other neurons, they are inhibited which means that they are less likely to \ re". Well-known benzodiazepines drugs like Valium, Librium, and Xanax enhance the inhibitory e ect of GABA thus reducing anxiety and having a calming and sedating e ect. The same as been observed for some metabolites of progesterone, i.e., substances converted from progesterone in the body. We 6The purpose of including a second saliva sample into the experiment was to study salivary hormone responses to pro ts in the auctions; see Schipper (2014). 7We thank Coren Apicella (private communication) for drawing our attention to the connection between progesterone and GABA A. 10hypothesize that the calming e ect of progestines in hormonal contraceptives may make females more risk averse in both the gain and loss domain. Moreover, because of the sedating e ect we hypothesize that they are less consistent in their choices. Note however that we cannot claim a causal e ect since any e ect may be due to selection. In particular, women who decide to take hormonal contraceptives may also di er systematically in their risk preferences from women who decide not to take any hormonal contraceptives. It is not clear whether a priori more risk averse women are more likely to use hormonal contraceptives or whether women with more risky sexual behavior are more likely to take hormonal contraceptives. Conclusive evidence could be obtained in an experiment in which oral contraceptives or a placebo are blindly and randomly assigned to women. Obviously, such an experiment would be rather dicult to conduct. Moreover, women who would agree to participate in such a \risky" experiment may systematically di er in their risk preferences from the rest of the population. Menstrual Cycle Fecundity varies over the menstrual cycle. It is not clear from an evolutionary point of view why risk aversion should stay constant throughout the menstrual cycle since gains and losses of risky behavior vary of the cycle. On one hand, risky behavior may lead to a higher probability of conception, genetic diversity and higher quality o spring through extrapair mating. This may be especially successful in monogamous societies where some females must be matched with genetically substandard males. Thus females with risky behavior near ovulation may have a higher reproductive success. On the other hand, extrapair mating involves the risk of losses because if discovered it is punished severely in most societies and may lead to a loss of the long term mating partner who supports child rearing.8This is signi cant because males of higher genetic quality tend to have poorer parental qualities (Gangestad and Simpson, 2000). These arguments suggest that in order to maximize tness over the menstrual cycle, a female should have the highest propensity for extrapair mating during her fecund period. Bressan and Stranieri (2008) show that partnered women favor single men with more masculine features during their fecund phase, while they prefer attached men during their low-fecundity phase.9 Wilcox et al. (2004) show that the frequency of intercourse increases during the fecund period.10 We hypothesize that females may behave more risky during their fecund period of the menstrual cycle, the peri-ovulatory phase. 8There is some evidence for greater mate guarding near ovulation (see Gangestad, Thorndill, and Garver, 2002, and Haselton and Gangestad, 2006), which may be a long-term male mate's best response to riskier behavior of the female during her fecund window and may in turn require more risky behavior of females to escape the guard. Yet, in humans, ovulation is concealed (to some extent even to the female herself) and thus time-targeted mate guarding must be rather limited. 9For related evidence, see Gangestad, Thornhill, and Garver-Apgar (2006), Penton-Voak et al. (2004), evidence is provided only for women in stable relationships. 11The hypothesis that women may behave more risk-taking during their fecund phase of their cycle seems to contradict Br oder and Hohmann (2003), who report that women avoid taking risks near ovulation in order to reduce the chance of being raped (see also Chavanne and Gallup, 1998, for an earlier study).11In contrast, Fessler (2003) argues that rape is not less frequent during the ovulatory phase. The experiment by Br oder and Hohmann (2003) did not discriminate between risks in the gain and loss domains. Di erences in risk preferences between the gain and loss domains have been discussed since the emergence of prospect theory (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979). Such risk preferences may be relevant in an evolutionary context (see Hamo and Heifetz, 2002, for some evolutionary arguments for such s-shaped utility functions). It is conceivable that women are more likely to avoid the risk of losses during the fecund phase but are also more likely to embrace risk of gains. Figure 1: Menstrual Cycle Some hormones such as progesterone vary across the menstrual cycle (see Figure 1) (see for instance, Chatterton et al., 2005). While salivary testosterone has been studied previously for choice under risk in the gain domain, we are not aware of any previous study of choice under risk for both gains and losses and all of salivary testosterone, estradiol, progesterone, and cortisol in both males and females . We show null results except for testosterone and cortisol. With regard to testosterone, we replicate the observation in Apicella et al. (2008) for males with a di erent lottery task in the gain domain only. In males, risk-taking for gains is positively associated with testosterone. The e ect size is small (likely to be attenuated by measure errors) but the nding is robust. We also observe that risk aversion for gains is positively associated with cortisol in females. This last nding has potential methodological implications for experimental economics. It is known that cortisol follows a circadian cycle. It is usually higher in the morning and then falls in the afternoon. It is also known to be a ected by stress such as exams etc. Thus, a careful experimenter should control for session e ects when experimenting with tasks in which behavior is sensitive to risk preferences especially if sessions are run both in the mornings and afternoons or during exam times. Both estradiol and progesterone vary over the menstrual cycle. Consistent with our null results on the correlation of risk preferences with salivary estradiol and progesterone, we also observe null results on the correlation of risk preferences with menstrual cycle phases. Our null nding with respect to hormonal contraceptives is consistent with the null result on salivary progesterone too since hormonal contraceptives contain an synthetic version of progesterone. Nevertheless, the null- nding for progesterone is puzzling because in our companion study, Schipper (2014), we report a robust positive association between basal progesterone and bidding of naturally cycling females in rst-price auctions. The e ects of risk aversion in rst-price auctions with symmetric independent private values are well established in theory (see Krishna, 2002, Chapter 4.1). Risk aversion increases equilibrium bids above risk-neutral Nash equilibrium. 35A higher bid translates into a higher probability of winning the auction, but it also leads to a lower pro t conditional on winning the auction.22The experimental evidence for risk aversion in rst-price auctions with symmetric independent private values is at best mixed (see for a survey, Kagel, 1995). Indeed, Schipper (2014) nds that the addition of our measures of risk preferences from our Holt-Laury lottery tasks to regressions of bidding on salivary progesterone does not diminish the positive association of bidding with progesterone. Thus, the association of progesterone on bidding does not seem to be mediated through risk preferences as elicited with Holt-Laury lotteries. This is somehow at odds with the literature showing that progesterone seems to mitigate \social risk" (Fleischman and Fessler, 2011, Maner and Wirth, and Stanton, 2004, Wirth and Schultheiss, 2006, Brown et al., 2009). One explanation for reconciling the evidence is that risk preferences are context-speci c rather than universal. Individual behavior in Holt-Laury lottery tasks may not be well-suited to measure risk attitudes in strategic contexts like auctions. The context-speci ty of risk attitudes may also explain to some extent poor correlations between behavior in the Holt-Laury lottery task and other elicitation methods (see Deck et al., 2010, and L onnqvist et al., 2011). Our null-results on the digit ratio are consistent with some of the existing literature. We replicate null-results for gains with a racially mixed sample of males by Apicella et al. (2008) and extend it to losses as well as a females. The null- nding is relevant given the positive ndings on the digit ratio and risk preferences reported in published research (see for a survey Ho man, Jordan, and Yoeli, 2013). It is also relevant given the positive ndings on the digit ratio and various economic behaviors both in the lab and the eld. Coates, Gurnell, and Rustichini (2009) nd that lower 2D:4D predicts the 20-month average pro tability of 44 male high-frequency traders in London. Guiso and Rustichini (2011) report that entrepreneurs with lower digit ratio manage larger rms and experience faster average growth. Van den Bergh and Dewitte (2006) report that in ultimatum bargaining games men with lower 2D:4D are more likely to reject unfair o ers in neutral contexts but are morel likely to accept unfair o ers in sex-related contexts. Using a public good game, Millet and Dewitte (2006) nd that men and women with lower digit ratio contribute proportionally, whereas those with higher 2D:4D contributed either more or less. Sanchez-Pages and Turiegano (2011) show that men with intermediate 2D:4D are more likely to cooperate in a one-shot prisoners' dilemma game. Our paper is related to an increasing literature on endocrinological economics. Pearson and Schipper (2012) show a null result for the correlation between the digit ratio and competitive bidding and pro ts in rst-price auctions. B Salivary Hormone Methodology B.1 Steroid Hormones Sex di erences in brain and behavior are to a large extent in uenced by sex steroids. According to the classic organizational-activational hypothesis of sexual di erentiation (see Phoenix et al, 1959), a transient rise in testosterone during prenatal or early postnatal development masculinizes the brain in males, while the absence of testosterone leads to female neural structures. During puberty, testicular and ovarian hormones act on previously sexually di erentiated circuits to facilitate expression of sex-typical behaviors in particular social contexts (see Schultz et al., 2009, Arnold and Breedlove, 1985, and Kelly et ial., 1999). Thus, sex steroids are thought to have both organizational e ects and activational e ects. Organizational e ects refer to more permanent in uences that often occur prenatally, early after birth, or during puberty. An example is the prenatal organization of tissues of male adult reproductive behavior. Activational e ects are temporary e ects and often they depend on prior organizational e ects. For instance, a male does not display mating behavior facilitated by the prenatally organized tissues unless adequate sex hormones are produced at puberty (see Baron-Cohen et al. 2006). Often, exogenous hormones are distinguished from endogenous hormones. The latter are hormones released by glands in the body, while exogenous hormones are hormones administered orally, transdermally, intranasally, or by various types of injections. Exogenous hormones may have e ects di erent from endogenous hormones of the same type depending on absorbtion, metabolism, and the presence of prior organizational e ects mentioned above. For instance, orally administered steroids are subject to the rst-pass e ect, i.e., the metabolic reduction of the steroid in the liver, and not all of the administered dose becomes available in the blood for binding on receptors. We focus on four endogenous steroid hormones: testosterone, estradiol, progesterone, and cortisol (for Nelson, 2011). Testosterone, C19H28O2, belongs to the androgen group. It is derived via some intermediated steps from cholesterol and secreted in the testis, ovaries, and adrenal gland. Some of it is aromatized into estradiol. Since it is observed in most vertebrates, it must have had a long evolutionary history (Mechoulam et al., 1984). Testosterone has anabolic e ects such as stimulating the bone density and muscle mass as well as androgenic e ects such as the maturation of sex organs and secondary sex characteristics especially in males. It is necessary for sperm development. In humans, various behavioral correlations with testosterone have been reported mostly pertaining to aggression (e.g. Archer, 1991) and dominance (e.g. Mazur and Booth, 1998, Mehta and Josephs, 2006). Estradiol,C18H24O2, sometimes also named E2 or 17 -estradiol, is a member of the estrogen group. It is also derived via some intermediated steps from cholesterol and secreted in the testis, ovaries, and the adrenal cortex. It changes over the menstrual cycle, peaking shortly before ovulation and again in the second half of the cycle (see Fritz and Spero , 2011). However, in blood plasma, estradiol is bound to globulin and albumin, and only a small fraction is free and biologically active. This fraction is constant over the menstrual cycle (Wu et al., 1976). Estradiol enters cells relatively freely. Its anabolic e ects include e ects on the bone structure and its androgenic e ects are on the maturation of female sex organs and secondary sex characteristics. Wu et al. (2009) suggest that the aromatization of testosterone into estradiol is important for the organization and activation of neural circuits that control male territorial behaviors in mice. Progesterone, C201H300O200, sometimes denoted by P4, belongs to the progesten group. It is derived from cholesterol, secreted in the ovaries, especially the corpus luteum, the adrenal glands, and during pregnancy in the placenta. It is also contained in milk. Progesterone is stored in fat tissue. It can be metabolized (via some intermediate steps) into cortisol, testosterone, and estradiol. Progesterone changes over the menstrual cycle, rising after ovulation and declining before menstruation (see Fritz and Spero , 2011). As its name suggests, it plays a prominent role during pregnancy (\pro-gestation"). Progesterone is a neurosteroid that can be synthesized within the central nervous system. There is a surprisingly small literature on behavioral e ects in humans; see Fleischman and Fessler (2011), Maner and (2014), Schultheiss, Wirth, and Stanton (2004), Wirth and Schultheiss (2006), and Brown et al. (2009). Cortisol,C21H30O5, is a steroid hormone belonging to glucocorticoid group. It is secreted in adrenal iiglands and controlled by the hypothalamus. It is considered to be the \stress hormone" since it is released in response to stress (Hellhammer, Wuest, and Kudielka, 2009). It increases blood sugar, suppresses the immune system, and is aiding fat, protein, and carbohydrate metabolism. As the other steroid hormones, it is derived from cholesterol via some intermediated steps. Massage (Field et al. 2005), intimacy (Ditzen et al., 2007, 2008), and sexual arousal (Hamilton and Meston, 2011) reduce cortisol levels. Ca eine (Lovallo et al., 2006) and sleep deprivation (Leproult et al, 1997) can increase cortisol levels. Cortisol follows a typical circadian cycle. On average it is lowest at 4:00 am and peaks at 8:00 am. In terms of behavioral e ects, cortisol may interact with testosterone. For instance, Mehta and Josephs (2010) report that testosterone is positively correlated with dominance in low cortisol males while negatively correlated in high cortisol males.
